Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a FlowCam to enhance Marine Science Research and Education at the University of New England
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of New England (UNE) in Biddeford, Maine, to acquire a FlowCam Imaging Particle Analysis System to strengthen instrumentation for multidisciplinary research and teaching at a primary undergraduate institution. The FlowCam system will allow multiple faculty to extend their current work to the "plankton/particulate" level, and/or start new plankton/particulate-oriented projects. The FlowCam will also be used in teaching of multiple classes in several departments, in local high schools, and will support undergraduate research projects in context of a current NSF IUSE grant. Every year more than 430 undergraduates in at least 7 courses at UNE and at least 120 high school students at 2 high schools will work on FlowCam projects.

Phytoplankton, zooplankton and detritus play important roles in the oceans food webs as primary producers and key food sources at the base of the food web. Including plankton/particulate-level analyses in studies on the reproduction of invasive species, fish diversity, bivalve feeding and growth rates and more will significantly increase our understanding of the respective processes and benefit several key local marine issues. Research projects will include such diverse areas as: interactions between two invasive crustacean crab species, a long-term biomonitoring study on phyto- and zooplankton, ichthyoplankton distribution and diversity in a small river plume, field investigations of the use of detritus by bivalves, plankton composition and structure in four lakes as it relates to climate change and watershed perturbations, and flow imaging technology for evaluation of elastin-like polymer coacervates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of a FlowCam truly enhanced Marine Science Research and Education at the University of New England. The FlowCam Particle Imager allows for rapid analysis of plankton or other particulate samples. A group of 5 faculty in Marine Sciences and in Chemistry investigated a broad range of projects, including multiple undergraduate and graduate students. Furthermore, the FlowCam is by now established as a teaching tool in several classes, allowing students an unprecedented ability to investigate plankton communities.

We investigated larval stages on invasive crustacean species and correlated larvae abundance with environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis. A poster on this project presented at a national conference earned the student presenter the first place as best student presentation by the Crustacean Society. A different project monitored detritus abundance in a mussel aquaculture farm, and then correlated detritus levels with feeding status of farmed blue mussels. This project was part of an NSF EPSCoR funded PhD thesis. Other masters thesis projects investigated free living zooxanthellae, as well as virus infection in phytoplankton.  Working at the lower end of the detection limit, we used the FlowCam to assess chemical macromolecules, Elastin-like Polymer Coacervates.

In the 3 year funding period we involved one PhD student, 3 Masters student, and at least a dozen undergraduate students in research projects. Students presented their findings at regional and national conferences as posters and talks, and some became co-authors on peer-reviewed publications.

By using the FlowCam in teaching labs in marine sciences classes in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd year we expose all of our Marine Science students (more than 100 per year) to the FlowCam technology. This allows us to teach plankton-related material with a research-oriented and inquisition-based approach.

Overall, the FlowCam opened up for us completely new research and teaching opportunities. The instrument will continue to be available for any student and/or faculty at UNE and will continue to serve an important role in our educational mission.
